name: Víknaslóðir Hiking Trails
description:
Víknaslóðir (the Deserted Inlets Trails) is an exceptional multi-day hiking route in Iceland's remote East Fjords region, traversing a landscape of abandoned farms, dramatic fjords, and coastal mountains that showcase the rugged beauty and historical poignancy of this isolated area. The trail system covers approximately 150 kilometers of the East Fjords coastline, broken into manageable day-hike sections that can be completed independently or as part of longer treks. The routes pass through landscapes once inhabited by farming and fishing communities but now largely abandoned, with ruins of turf houses and farms scattered along the trails serving as reminders of the challenging life people led in these remote coastal valleys. The combination of dramatic scenery, historical interest, and relative solitude makes Víknaslóðir one of Iceland's most rewarding long-distance hiking experiences.

The trails follow ancient footpaths that connected isolated communities before road construction made coastal travel easier. Hikers traverse diverse terrain including coastal cliffs with seabird colonies, river valleys, mountain passes, black sand beaches, and stretches of dramatic coastline where mountains plunge directly into the sea. The area is rich in wildlife, with Arctic foxes, reindeer (unique to East Iceland), seals, and various seabird species commonly encountered. The abandoned farms along the route have historical significance—some date back to Iceland's settlement period, and their stories reflect the broader patterns of rural depopulation that characterized 20th-century Iceland. Many sections of trail pass through extraordinarily beautiful and isolated landscapes that see very few visitors, providing genuine wilderness experiences increasingly rare in modern Iceland. The changing perspectives as the trail moves from fjord to fjord showcase the East Fjords' complex topography and dramatic geology.

Hiking Víknaslóðir requires substantial planning and self-sufficiency. Accommodations along the route include basic mountain huts, farmhouse guesthouses, and camping areas, but hikers must plan stages carefully and book accommodations in advance. The trail is typically accessible from June through September, with July and August providing the most reliable weather and longest daylight. Weather in the East Fjords can be extremely variable, with fog, rain, and wind common even in summer, so proper equipment and clothing are essential. While individual sections can be hiked as day trips, many hikers complete the route over 5-8 days, allowing time to appreciate the landscape and explore side trails and points of interest. The trailheads are accessible from various points along the East Fjords section of Route 1, making it possible to design customized itineraries. For experienced hikers seeking a less crowded alternative to popular routes like Laugavegur, Víknaslóðir offers exceptional landscapes, historical depth, and the satisfaction of exploring one of Iceland's most beautiful and under-visited regions.
opening_hours: Best hiked June-September. Multi-day trek (5-8 days typical) or individual day sections. Book huts in advance. High self-sufficiency required.
